somewhere near there is when all the bacteria in the meat is cooked off, so

meat, if done the right way

comments.text:
+Camberwell86 That's not true. The salt will draw the moisture from the 
steak (some people say it dries the steak, some people say it concentrates 
the flavours.) Interestingly, when pre-salted steaks have been analysed 
after cooking, traces of iron from the pan have been found on them. 
Seemingly, the salt reacts with the pan, catalysing a chemical bonding 
process. 

Of course, that doesn't sound appetising, but it's perfectly safe, and is 
probably contributing to that superior flavour many people enjoy and 
(erroneously) associate with a well-seasoned steak.

Personally, I prefer the flavour of a pre-seasoned steak, but that flavour 
is not due to salt penetrating the meat.

comments.text:
Okay let me help you guys out. EVOO smokes and burns a lot FASTER than 
other oils such as ground nut. The smoke point does not matter. The 
difference is how fast it burns. EVOO burns very quickly, while groundnut 
and grapeseed (my preference) burn very slowly. Put simply, EVOO will smoke 
and turn to nothing within seconds, whereas groundnut will smoke for quite 
some time. 

So, when you're cooking a steak, the oil that's burning and smoking won't 
transfer heat as well as grapeseed. This results in a very poor 
caramelization. Look at 3:47, the bottom of the steak. There's literally no 
color. Then look at Ramsey's video. A nice crispy outside, tender inside. 
So +Alexander Trefz, before you spout out more bullshit, actually go to the 
kitchen and try different oils. 

And remember, we're talking about the guy that thinks flipping a steak 
multiple times somehow keeps the juices in. Pseudo-molecular gastronomy at 
its finest.
